rating_criteria.description: Sleep apnea is rated based on treatment requirements and severity of symptoms

levels.criteria: Asymptomatic but with documented sleep disorder breathing
Requires use of breathing assistance device such as continuous airway pressure (CPAP) machine
Chronic respiratory failure with carbon dioxide retention or cor pulmonale, or requires tracheostomy

diagnostic_types.description: Most common type; airway becomes blocked during sleep
Brain doesn't properly control breathing during sleep

diagnosis_requirements.description: The diagnosis of sleep apnea MUST be confirmed by a sleep study (polysomnography)

for_service_connection: Evidence of in-service symptoms or diagnosis
Nexus letter linking current condition to service
Buddy statements about snoring/breathing issues in service

tips_for_veterans: ALWAYS bring your sleep study results to the exam
Bring proof of CPAP prescription and usage
Document how sleep apnea affects your daily life and work
Mention daytime sleepiness and how severe it is
Report if you've ever fallen asleep while driving or at work
Describe impact on concentration and memory
Mention if sleep apnea affects your relationships
If secondary to another condition (like PTSD), bring documentation
Keep CPAP compliance records if available
Document all medications taken for sleep
common_mistakes: Not having a sleep study on record
Not connecting sleep apnea to potential secondary conditions

secondary_service_connection.description: Sleep apnea can be secondary to or aggravated by other service-connected conditions

common_primaries.connection: Research shows strong bidirectional relationship; PTSD can cause or worsen sleep apnea
Nasal obstruction can contribute to OSA
Psychiatric medications often cause weight gain, which is a major risk factor for OSA
TBI can affect breathing control centers

secondary_service_connection.nexus_language: The veteran's sleep apnea is at least as likely as not (50% or greater probability) caused by OR aggravated by [service-connected condition]

important_notes: Sleep study is REQUIRED for diagnosis - clinical diagnosis alone is insufficient
CPAP use gets you 50% rating - this is the most common rating
100% rating requires severe complications (respiratory failure, tracheostomy)
Sleep apnea is increasingly being service-connected secondary to PTSD
Weight gain from service-connected medications can support secondary connection
